sn39.1-15:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā sāriputto vajjīsu viharati ukkacelāyaṃ gaṅgāya nadiyā tīre.
sn39.1-15:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying in the land of the Vajjis near Ukkacelā on the bank of the Ganges river.

sn39.1-15:1.2.pli: Atha kho sāmaṇḍako paribbājako yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn39.1-15:1.2.eng: Then the wanderer Sāmaṇḍaka went up to Venerable Sāriputta and exchanged greetings with him.

sn39.1-15:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sāmaṇḍako paribbājako āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
sn39.1-15:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Sāriputta:

sn39.1-15:2.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, they speak of this thing called ‘extinguishment’.

sn39.1-15:2.3.eng: “Reverend, the ending of greed, hate, and delusion

sn39.1-15:2.5.pli: “Atthi panāvuso, maggo atthi paṭipadā, etassa nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti?
sn39.1-15:2.5.eng: “But, reverend, is there a path and a practice for realizing this extinguishment?”

sn39.1-15:2.6.pli: “Atthi kho, āvuso, maggo atthi paṭipadā, etassa nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.

sn39.1-15:3.1.pli: “Katamo panāvuso, maggo katamā paṭipadā etassa nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti?

sn39.1-15:3.2.pli: “Ayameva kho, āvuso, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, etassa nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, seyyathidaṃ—
sn39.1-15:3.2.eng: “It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn39.1-15:3.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn39.1-15:3.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā, etassa nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
sn39.1-15:3.4.eng: This is the path, the practice, for realizing this extinguishment.”

sn39.1-15:3.5.pli: “Bhaddako, āvuso, maggo bhaddikā paṭipadā, etassa nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya.
sn39.1-15:3.5.eng: “Reverend, this is a fine path, a fine practice, for realizing this extinguishment.

sn39.1-15:3.6.eng: Just this much is enough to be diligent.”

sn39.1-15:4.1.eng: (Tell in full  as the Linked Discourses with Jambukhādaka.)

sn39.16:1.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye dukkaran”ti?
sn39.16:1.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, in this teaching and training, what is hard to do?”

sn39.16:1.2.eng: “Going forth, reverend, is hard to do in this teaching and training.”

sn39.16:1.3.eng: “But what’s hard to do for someone who has gone forth?”

sn39.16:1.4.eng: “When you’ve gone forth it’s hard to be satisfied.”

sn39.16:1.5.eng: “But what’s hard to do for someone who is satisfied?”

sn39.16:1.6.eng: “When you’re satisfied, it’s hard to practice in line with the teaching.”

sn39.16:1.7.eng: “But if a mendicant practices  in line with the teaching, will it take them long to become a perfected one?”

sn39.16:1.11.eng: The Linked Discourses with Sāmaṇḍaka are complete.

sn40.1:0.3.eng: A Question About the First Absorption

sn40.1:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn40.1:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn40.1:1.2.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn40.1:1.2.eng: There Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants:

sn40.1:1.4.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa paccassosuṃ.

sn40.1:2.1.pli: “Idha mayhaṃ, āvuso, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn40.1:2.1.eng: “Just now, reverends, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:

sn40.1:2.2.eng: ‘They speak of this thing called the “first absorption”.

sn40.1:2.5.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn40.1:2.5.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn40.1:2.6.eng: This is called the first absorption.’

sn40.1:2.7.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn40.1:2.7.eng: And so … I was entering and remaining in the first absorption.

sn40.1:2.8.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato kāmasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti.
sn40.1:2.8.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by sensual pleasures beset me.

sn40.1:3.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn40.1:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

sn40.1:3.3.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ pamādo, paṭhame jhāne cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, paṭhame jhāne cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, paṭhame jhāne cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
sn40.1:3.3.eng: Don’t neglect the first absorption, brahmin! Settle your mind in the first absorption; unify your mind and immerse it in the first absorption.’

sn40.1:3.4.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
sn40.1:3.4.eng: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the first absorption.

sn40.1:3.5.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn40.1:3.5.eng: So if anyone should be rightly called

sn40.1:3.6.pli: ‘satthārānuggahito sāvako mahābhiññataṃ patto’ti, mamaṃ taṃ sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn40.1:3.6.eng: a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

sn40.10:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—jetavane antarahito devesu tāvatiṃsesu pāturahosi.
sn40.10:1.1.eng: And then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared among the gods of the thirty-three.

sn40.10:1.2.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcahi devatāsatehi saddhiṃ yenāyasmā mahāmoggallāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno etadavoca:
sn40.10:1.2.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, with five hundred deities came up to Mahāmoggallāna, bowed, and stood to one side. Mahāmoggallāna said to him:

sn40.10:2.1.eng: “Lord of gods, it’s good to go for refuge to the Buddha.

sn40.10:2.2.pli: Buddhasaraṇagamanahetu kho, devānaminda, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
sn40.10:2.2.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn40.10:2.3.eng: It’s good to go for refuge to the teaching.

sn40.10:2.4.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn40.10:2.5.eng: It’s good to go for refuge to the Saṅgha.

sn40.10:2.6.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”

sn40.10:7.1.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcahi devatāsatehi saddhiṃ yenāyasmā mahāmoggallāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno etadavoca:
sn40.10:7.1.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, with five hundred deities came up to Mahāmoggallāna, bowed, and stood to one side. Mahāmoggallāna said to him:

sn40.10:8.1.pli: “Sādhu kho, devānaminda, buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgamanaṃ hoti:
sn40.10:8.1.eng: “Lord of gods, it’s good to have experiential confidence in the Buddha:

sn40.10:8.2.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
sn40.10:8.2.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn40.10:8.3.pli: Buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgamanahetu kho, devānaminda, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
sn40.10:8.3.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn40.10:9.1.pli: Sādhu kho, devānaminda, dhamme aveccappasādena samannāgamanaṃ hoti:
sn40.10:9.1.eng: It’s good to have experiential confidence in the teaching:

sn40.10:9.2.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
sn40.10:9.2.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

sn40.10:9.3.pli: Dhamme aveccappasādena samannāgamanahetu kho, devānaminda, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
sn40.10:9.3.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn40.10:10.1.pli: Sādhu kho, devānaminda, saṅghe aveccappasādena samannāgamanaṃ hoti:
sn40.10:10.1.eng: It’s good to have experiential confidence in the Saṅgha:

sn40.10:10.2.pli: ‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā’ti.
sn40.10:10.2.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’

sn40.10:10.3.pli: Saṅghe aveccappasādena samannāgamanahetu kho, devānaminda, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
sn40.10:10.3.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

sn40.10:11.1.pli: Sādhu kho, devānaminda, ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgamanaṃ hoti akhaṇḍehi acchiddehi asabalehi akammāsehi bhujissehi viññuppasatthehi aparāmaṭṭhehi samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn40.10:11.1.eng: It’s good to have the ethical conduct that’s loved by the noble ones, unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

sn40.10:11.2.pli: Ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgamanahetu kho, devānaminda, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjantī”ti.
sn40.10:11.2.eng: It’s the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”
